intro: Tibetiodes salwinensis, commonly known as the Salwin Tibetian bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of Tibet and northern Burma. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are often hairy as well. Due to its restricted habitat, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
